Looking at the Visual Merge Window

 

 

Visual Merge can combine two text files that are different but are based on the same application revision. Typically, it is used when one file has already been checked into the application, but the other file needs to be checked in from a working folder. However, it may also be used during the check-out process (see Merging Files).

The Visual Merge window allows three-way merges:

  • The upper left pane displays the differences between the mutual ancestor file and the tip revision.

  • The upper right pane displays the differences between the mutual ancestor and the file in your working folder.

  • The lower pane shows the three-way merge of the files in the upper panes with their mutual ancestor. This merge displays the text suggested for the file that will be checked in.

The default text colors and styles that appear in the upper panes of the Visual Merge window are:

  • Blue italicized text indicates changed (and, therefore, conflicting) blocks of text.

  • Red text with strikethrough indicates deleted blocks of text.

  • Green indicates inserted blocks of text.

  • Black indicates matching blocks of text.

The merged file in the lower pane uses no identifying colors or styles. This pane is the only one that you can edit, although you can copy text to it from either of the upper panes.
